thread.title: Toby Keith: ‘I Don’t Apologize For Performing For Our Country Or…’
thread.title_full: Toby Keith: ‘I Don’t Apologize For Performing For Our Country Or…’

author: Randy DeSoto
title: Toby Keith: ‘I Don’t Apologize For Performing For Our Country Or…’
text:
Rosie O’Donnell Just Took Things To The Next Level In War Against Trump 
Keith penned and recorded the patriotic tune Courtesy of the Red, White, and Blue promising justice to those who perpetrated the 9/11 attacks. 
The song topped the country music chart and hit No. 25 on the Billboard Top 100 in 2002. Advertisement - story continues below 
The native Oklahoman was named the Country Music Association’s male vocalist of the year in 2001 and garnered the music video of the year in 2012. He has recorded more than 20 No. 1 country music hits spanning his 20-plus-year career. Singer and Broadway actress Jennifer Holliday, who was also announced as one of the acts in Trump’s celebration concert, backed out over the weekend. 
After an uproar online, she wrote an open letter on Saturday: “I was honestly just thinking that I wanted my voice to be a healing and unifying force for hope through music to help our deeply polarized country.” 
She added, “Regretfully, I did not take into consideration that my performing for the concert would actually instead be taken as a political act against my own personal beliefs and be mistaken for support of Donald Trump and Mike Pence.” The artist conveyed that she particularly did not want to offend her fans in the LGBT community. 
“I sincerely apologize for my lapse of judgment,” Holliday wrote. Advertisement - story continues below
